Mickey 17 is another prime example of Bong Joon Ho’s remarkable ability to craft a film rich in social commentary and thematic relevance. A film that heavily satirizes the current state of politics, Mickey 17 does not fear touching on subjects of capitalism, corruption, and colonialism. Blending the genres of comedy and science fiction, Mickey 17 maintains a lighthearted tone despite touching on such heavy subject matters. Bong Joon Ho delivers his most science fiction story yet, though there are some interesting similarities to The Host and Okja, and I can certainly see Mickey 17 be one of Bong Joon Ho’s most polarizing films. With its fair amount of ridiculousness, there are moments where the humor does feel a little too jarring to the overall story. However, the performances throughout Mickey 17 are fantastic. 

Robert Pattinson shines as both the lead role and as a supporting one. Delivering two great performances, it becomes more apparent that Robert Pattinson is one of the most talented actors working today. While Pattinson delivers the best performances in Mickey 17, Mark Ruffalo delivers the most memorable one. Ruffalo is entertainingly ridiculous in his performance that satirizes corrupt politicians. Through his silly mannerisms and comedic facial expressions, Ruffalo highlights a career standout performance. The supporting performances from Naomi Ackie, Steven Yuen, and Toni Collette also contribute to the overall success of Mickey 17. The dynamic between Naomi Ackie and Robert Pattinson is crucial to the heart and emotion of Mickey 17, but it’s Bong Joon Ho’s ability to infuse an emotional connection between the audience at the “Creeper” creatures that is the most impressive. 

Overall, Mickey 17 is Bong Joon Ho’s longest film, yet there is no dull period and the film flows smoothly. With brilliant visual effects and beautiful cinematography, Mickey 17 is science fiction storytelling at its most interesting. Robert Pattinson is phenomenal and Bong Joon Ho brings out one of the best performances of his filmography. With Bong Joon Ho writing the adapted screenplay and directing the film, Mickey 17 is explosive, exhilarating, and dynamic.
The work manages to bring good and current political criticism, but the plot that structures it, in general, is not that exciting.

Despite making movies for over 2 decades, Bong Joon Ho really didn’t burst onto the world scene until he made Parasite, one of the best films of 2019. Maybe the expectations for his follow up were just too high, and while Mickey 17 is certainly ambitious, it seems that even a craftsman like Bong has found his reach extending his grasp on this one. It presents an equally bleak and warped view of the future, where the earth is failing and the only solution is to look for another world to relocate to. Bong has always exceled at social criticism, but it was usually smart and cleverly worked into the narrative. Here it’s so in your face that it becomes distracting and even annoying. The parody of modern-day politicians, one in particular, as well as the other issues it tries to address are so ham-fisted and over the top that they just made me eyeroll. I’m all for taking shots at real life figures and phenomena, but when you go for the easiest targets every time and hit them as often as possible, it just feels like you’re riding a bandwagon. The exhaustive narrations suggestions that there’s so much that they couldn’t work into the film so is just explained to us via voiceover, and the performances range from compelling to downright cartoonish, with Mark Ruffalo, an actor I generally like, giving the kind of performance that couldn’t even be called scenery chewing. I won’t fault Bong for really going all out with this one rather than playing it safe, but I cant help but feel that trying to juggle so many different tones and so many different genres just undermines whatever the films message is. It the script had been tighter, the runtime shorter and the targets less scattershot, it could have ben something special. As it, it’s a disappointing, albeit remarkable, missed opportunity.

Mickey 17 é uma obra de ficção científica maravilhosa.

Tirando alguns clichês inevitáveis do gênero, o filme me pegou de jeito. A estética é impecável, o CGI é lindíssimo, e a crítica social por trás da história é GRITANTE — como já era de se esperar do Bong Joon-ho, que desde Parasita vem colocando o dedo na ferida.

O filme fala sobre um trabalhador CLONADO que é explorado e descartado como se fosse peça de reposição. Tem imperialismo, alienação, exploração da classe trabalhadora, e uma colonização planetária que funciona como metáfora direta de dominação e apagamento de culturas. Tudo isso embalado por uma ficção científica de altíssimo nível.

Robert Pattinson está ABSURDO. Atua com profundidade interpretando duas versões do Mickey, com personalidades diferentes, e a cena em que ele contracena com ele mesmo é nível altíssimo. É de longe uma das melhores atuações da carreira dele, e uma baita virada de página pra quem um dia foi zoado por Crepúsculo.

Naomi Ackie (Nasha) me surpreendeu muito. Não tava esperando tanto, e ela entregou com emoção e presença.

Steven Yeun (Timo) fez ali o café com leite daquele amigo babaca, mas também entregou um bom papel.

E a Ilpha, interpretada pela Toni Collette, merece destaque. Desde Hereditário, ela já mostrou que sabe entregar tudo — e aqui ela transita entre o cômico, o estranho e o dramático com naturalidade. Tem uma cena, sem dar spoiler, que dá até um calafrio ver ela atuando, especialmente quando o tom dela lembra o que ela fez em Hereditário. Foi só uma cena ou outra, coisa de poucos minutos, mas muito boa.

Mark Ruffalo faz aquele papel mais teatral, meio paspalhão, lembrando uma caricatura de líder americano tipo “Make America Great Again”. Parece que foi proposital, talvez até pedido do diretor.

No fim, Mickey 17 é tudo: crítica social, espetáculo visual, ficção científica de respeito.
Não é um filme pra todo mundo — mas eu tô feliz de não ser todo mundo.

Mickey 17 is a beautiful piece of science fiction.

Besides some expected genre clichés, the movie really pulled me in. The visuals are stunning, the CGI looks great, and the social commentary is LOUD — which is exactly what you'd expect from Bong Joon-ho after Parasite.

The plot follows a CLONED worker, created to be exploited and discarded like a tool. There’s imperialism, alienation, class exploitation, and planetary colonization used as a metaphor for domination and cultural erasure. All of it wrapped in high-level sci-fi.

Robert Pattinson is amazing. He brings depth to two different versions of Mickey, and the scene where he plays against himself is just incredible. Honestly, it’s one of the best performances of his career — a solid comeback after all the Twilight mockery.

Naomi Ackie (Nasha) really surprised me. I wasn’t expecting much, but she delivered with emotion and presence.

Steven Yeun (Timo) plays that kind of annoying friend character, but he also did a solid job.

And then there's Ilpha, played by Toni Collette, who deserves a proper shout-out. Since Hereditary, she’s shown she can do it all — and here she shifts between comedy, weirdness, and drama so naturally. There’s one scene — no spoilers — where she speaks in a tone that’s very reminiscent of Hereditary, and it gave me chills. Just a short moment, but really effective.

Mark Ruffalo plays a theatrical, over-the-top character — kind of a caricature of a “Make America Great Again” leader. It feels intentional, maybe even director-driven.

In the end, Mickey 17 brings it all: sharp social critique, amazing visuals, and strong sci-fi.
It’s not a movie for everyone — and I’m glad I’m not everyone.
Bong Joon-ho is still a powerhouse.

But it does seem to fumble around as the movie goes on... especially in the final act. While I really like Mark Ruffalo and I think he brings his all to this role, his character (along with a few others) lacks subtlety and depth in a way that I felt cheapened the story. Overall, it's a fun and engaging watch with a surprisingly romantic core. I'd easily recommend.

Mickey 17 feels more spiritually connected to Bong Joon Ho's genre-bending works like The Host and Snowpiercer than to his Oscar-winning Parasite. While undeniably flawed and occasionally heavy-handed with its political satire, the film offers something fresh and exciting in the sci-fi landscape.

The real standout is Robert Pattinson's remarkable performance as Mickey and his various clones. Each iteration feels distinctly different - a testament to Pattinson's range and commitment. When another Mickey appears on screen, you genuinely feel like you're watching a different person, despite the shared face. This virtuoso performance elevates the material considerably.

As with many of Bong's English-language films, some of his trademark dark comedy doesn't quite translate with the same razor-sharp edge we've come to expect from his Korean productions. The nuanced absurdism that made The Host so memorable feels somewhat diluted here, perhaps lost in translation or cultural context.

Still, there's an undeniable originality to Mickey 17 that keeps you engaged. The film's exploration of expendability and corporate exploitation resonates, even when the execution falters. It's imperfect sci-fi that's more forgiving in its genre, buoyed by creative world-building and Pattinson's multi-faceted turn.

For those willing to embrace its flaws, Mickey 17 offers an intriguing addition to Bong's diverse filmography.​​​​​​​​

“When a director is given too much power” that is the lesson that Mickey 17 teaches us. Mickey 17 is one of the first big-budget movies to come out in 2025. Directed by Bong Joon Ho, the same person who directed the cinematic masterpieces such as Parasite, the movie came out with high hopes from both critics and audiences alike. Unfortunately, the movie was not able to come close to the hype it had garnered.

Summary
Mickey 17 follows the story of Mickey. A man who volunteers to become a test subject on a space mission to escape the people who are chasing him on earth. In the movie’s universe, humanity has discovered how to clone people and uses ‘expendables’ (people that have the sole purpose of dying for scientific inquiry) to conduct experiments on the human body. Once the person dies, they can be cloned again, loaded with their past memories and used for future experiments. This goes wrong when the 17th version of Mickey is presumed to be dead and his 18th version is cloned. The movie then follows Mickey 17th as he returns to the ship and finds his place taken by his clone, Mickey 18th.

World Building
The movie does a good job of worldbuilding. A common mistakes that sci-fi movies make is to rely on exposition (people talking about the world around them) for worldbuilding instead of actually showing the world and its rules. Mickey 17 balances these 2 aspects well. From the start, we hear Mickey 17 as a inner monologue and are shown the things he talks about. This helps the audience understand the world without making it feel complicated. The problem happens, when you are an hour into the movie and Mickey is still monologueing. Representing a detailed description of the world and its rules is not necessarily a bad thing, done well, it can help the audience’s immersion. But when it takes an hour to explain the world and nothing important happens in the story other than Mickey 18th being formed (Which the audience already know about from the trailers), the audience tend to loose their attention and that point, no amount of fancy visuals can bring their attention back.

WHAT, WHEN, WHY
Every good movie needs to establish its What — what the main character hopes to accomplish; its When — the time by which they must achieve it; and its Why — the reason it matters. Without establishing these, a movie ends up being disfocused and lost in its plot. If the audience do not have a clear goal that needs to be achieved then everything ends up feeling pointless. This is the biggest mistake that Mickey 17 makes. From start to end, not once does the movie establish a clear goal that the characters need to achieve and a time frame for them to achieve it. There are some implicit goals and this can work, if, there is only one implicit goal and it is not interfered with. A movie cannot have multiple, unclear, implicit goals that are competing with one another. First, Mickey 17th has the implicit goal of following Mickey 18th. Why must he follow him? Because it’s a clone and he should. But then they meet and the goal ends. Now what, now they want to kill the head of the ship. Why? Because the captain treats them like expendables, but then everyone on the ship treats them like that, so they should logically kill everyone. But then, they fail. Now, they must save humanity. Why are they the ones saving humanity? Because they are the main characters, but there is nothing special about them, they might be clones but they are still humans, that isn’t a special ability. Boo Joon Ho uses the entire movie to showcase this amazing and detailed world he has created, but he never gives the audience a clear goal that Mickey 17th needs to achieve in this world.

Setups and Payoffs
Every movie needs setups and payoffs. The movie setups the goals that need to be achieved and then works towards the final payoff. This concept isn’t just limited to goals, a movie can setup a certain metaphor or external element and then use it later (this becomes the payoff). Unfortunately, for Mickey 17, this setup and payoff element is not executed well. Every movie is made of 3 acts, it’s introduction, main part, conclusion. Mickey 17 loosely sets up metaphors and goals in it’s first act and then rushes to close them up in the third act. The second act adds nothing to the movie and then continues to conflict and ruin the one implicit goal the first act set up. If you ignore the second act of the movie, all of it’s confusion and contradiction then the movie ends up being quite focused. Because, at the end of the movie, the only goals that are achieved are those set up in the first act. The second act goals are just ignored and forgotten by the movie.

Too many themes
The movie tries to tackle a lot of themes. Where a good movie only needs to tackle one or at max 2 themes. Mickey 17 tries to take on 3 of them: Ethics and Morality, Church and State, Situations and the Poor. A movie like Mickey 17 could have easily stuck to the ethics of making new people with the same memories (Some complicated story building also shows that it is not even the exact same memories). The storybuilding is also used to tackle the poverty theme and how it forces people into unfavourable situations. But then the movie decided to add a third theme. How the church and religion influnce the decisions made by the state (the captain). This theme is then not tackled in any meaningful way. It is represented to show it exists and then nothing is done with it. So the third theme ends up complicating the message of the movie without showing any meaningful messages of its own.

Conclusion
In conclusion. The movie looks amazing, from it’s quality to the colour grading to the wardrobe choices. The acting in Mickey 17 is phenomenal. Robert Pattinson does an amazing job of bringing his character to life. But other than these, there are no pros to it. It is a disfocused mess with no meaning or goal to it. Even the character arc is a lousy and unjustified mess. If you love Robert Pattinson and his work then maybe give it a try, but for any reasons other than that, skip it.

Mickey 17 é um thriller de ficção científica, com um leve toque cômico que promete ter trazido às telas novamente a magia do cineasta Bong Joon-ho (diretor do fantástico filme Parasita). Desde já, vou deixar claro que adorei o filme, e que deu pra notar nele a "assinatura" de Bong Joon-ho. O filme apresenta um futuro distópico bem elaborado, e imerge o espectador nele através de imagens alucinantes (sem grandes exageros) e boa ambientação. Também cria toda a "mitologia" (digamos assim), que não é muito complexa, nem mesmo muito realista, porém, não vejo como um problema, pois o filme não se leva à sério, adotando um tom cômico, tanto através das situações da trama e de certas "piadas", como também pelo personagem principal Mickey 17 (principalmente por ele), que é muito bem interpretado por Robert Pattinson. Esse personagem (Mickey 17) talvez pode não agradar muitas pessoas pelo seu jeito excessivamente caricato, infantilizado e etc., mas consegue roubar nossa simpatia, e é apoiado pelo tom do filme. O filme apresenta muitas críticas e subtextos e até mesmo alegorias que enriquecem mais a obra: crítica social, política, religiosa (infelizmente para quem é religioso) e até sobre colonização e fascismo. As demais atuações estão perfeitas, e quero destacar Mark Ruffalo, como o Sr. Marshall, ele é perfeito: engraçado, ridículo, vilanesco, quase que implacável e babaca também [kkkk]. Mas o mais impressionante é a habilidade única de Bong Joon-ho (diretor) de extrair o máximo das situações da trama, gerando tensão, alucinação e prendendo o espectador até o fim, sempre explorando as relações humanas da forma mais "roubada" (no bom sentido) possível. Por fim, não chega a repetir a qualidade de Parasita, porém não por demérito, mas sim por mérito de Parasita. É um filmaço, mas depende da sua identificação com a obra. Recomendo. Asha es la compañera del protagonista y los dos tienen una relación muy particular e íntima. El antagonista Kenneth Marshall es un dictador y el comandante de la naveta espacial donde se desarrolla la mayoría de la película. Kenneth y también su mujer son personajes muy  infamosos que casi todos odian también yo. El comienzo de la película es muy interesante porque vemos cómo funciona la máquina que hace las réplicas y las experimentaciones científicas. Robert Pattinson delivers an excellent performance, once again proving his versatility and commitment to unique roles. Mark Ruffalo also does a great job, as expected, though his character isn’t as impactful or layered as one might have hoped.

Visually, the film stands out with well-executed special effects and immersive world-building. In that regard, it’s a spectacle worth watching on the big screen.

Bong Joon-ho strikes cinematic gold once again with his latest sci-fi satire, Mickey 17. As always, Bong’s deft touch is evident in his exploration of a dystopian world, where he delivers a chillingly relevant critique of a fascist government. The timing of this film’s release is especially poignant, resonating not only with the political climate of the United States but with the global instability that looms over us all. Mark Ruffalo’s performance is a standout, delivering a portrayal that is both chilling and captivating. It’s clear that he drew heavy inspiration from a certain real-life figure, infusing his character with an intensity that leaves little to the imagination about his motivations and the dark, twisted psyche that drives him. Robert Pattinson, meanwhile, delivers a stunning dual performance as the titular Mickey, skillfully breathing unique life into two distinct iterations of the same character. His nuanced portrayal showcases his ability to differentiate the two versions, making each one feel fresh and dynamic, a feat that adds layers to the film’s complex narrative. Like many of Bong Joon-ho’s films, Mickey 17 is a work that rewards multiple viewings. Its rich, thought-provoking story and underlying themes will unfold more with each watch, revealing new layers and deeper meanings. This is a film that stays with you, demanding both reflection and interpretation long after the credits roll.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film. On the surface, it’s an excellent sci-fi, absurdist comedy/drama, with shades of Terry Gilliam, a drop of Wes Anderson, and a *smidgen* of Jean Pierre-Jeunet, and underneath is a beautiful (if confrontational) examination of capitalism, politics, religion, and the value of a single human life

This is a movie for people who like a puzzle, who ponder philosophy, who appreciate layered storytelling, and not for someone who just wants to sit down and turn their brain off. If you are one such who seeks to *connect* with a film, someone who searches for a tale with *meaning*, then I cannot recommend this one highly enough
